title: Aerial farming services in New Zealand
creator_contributor_role: Soil Conservation and Rivers Control Council, production company
subject_group: Armed Forces, Military, War & Weapons/Tiger Moth (Training planes)
Climate, Environment, Natural Resources & Disasters/Pest control
Agriculture, Business, Commerce & Industry/Spraying and dusting in agriculture
Agriculture, Business, Commerce & Industry/Agriculture - New Zealand
description: The use of aeroplanes in schemes for restoring eroded lands to former fertility by dropping fertilizers to improve pasture and poison to combat the rabbit menace. Shows Tiger Moth aircraft being fitted to spray chemical compounds; mechanical loading of fertilizer into planes; aircraft in flight and spraying from the air. Points out the saving in time and money that results from the use of aircraft.
